<sos>   i   <eos>
<sos>   1   <eos>
<sos> stately  plump buck mulligan came from the stairhead  bearing a bowl of <eos>
<sos> lather on which a mirror and a razor lay crossed  a yellow <eos>
<sos> dressinggown  ungirdled  was sustained gently behind him on the mild <eos>
<sos> morning air  he held the bowl aloft and intoned  <eos>
<sos>  introibo ad altare dei  <eos>
<sos> halted  he peered down the dark winding stairs and called out coarsely  <eos>
<sos>  come up  kinch  come up  you fearful jesuit  <eos>
<sos> solemnly he came forward and mounted the round gunrest  he faced about <eos>
<sos> and blessed gravely thrice the tower  the surrounding land and the <eos>
<sos> awaking mountains  then  catching sight of stephen dedalus  he bent <eos>
<sos> towards him and made rapid crosses in the air  gurgling in his throat <eos>
<sos> and shaking his head  stephen dedalus  displeased and sleepy  leaned <eos>
<sos> his arms on the top of the staircase and looked coldly at the shaking <eos>
<sos> gurgling face that blessed him  equine in its length  and at the light <eos>
<sos> untonsured hair  grained and hued like pale oak  <eos>
<sos> buck mulligan peeped an instant under the mirror and then covered the <eos>
<sos> bowl smartly  <eos>
<sos>  back to barracks  he said sternly  <eos>
<sos> he added in a preacher is tone  <eos>
<sos>  for this  o dearly beloved  is the genuine christine  body and soul <eos>
<sos> and blood and ouns  slow music  please  shut your eyes  gents  one <eos>
<sos> moment  a little trouble about those white corpuscles  silence  all  <eos>
<sos> he peered sideways up and gave a long slow whistle of call  then paused <eos>
<sos> awhile in rapt attention  his even white teeth glistening here and <eos>
<sos> there with gold points  chrysostomos  two strong shrill whistles <eos>
<sos> answered through the calm  <eos>
<sos>  thanks  old chap  he cried briskly  that will do nicely  switch off <eos>
<sos> the current  will you  <eos>
<sos> he skipped off the gunrest and looked gravely at his watcher  gathering <eos>
<sos> about his legs the loose folds of his gown  the plump shadowed face and <eos>
<sos> sullen oval jowl recalled a prelate  patron of arts in the middle ages  <eos>
<sos> a pleasant smile broke quietly over his lips  <eos>
<sos>  the mockery of it  he said gaily  your absurd name  an ancient greek  <eos>
<sos> he pointed his finger in friendly jest and went over to the parapet  <eos>
<sos> laughing to himself  stephen dedalus stepped up  followed him wearily <eos>
<sos> halfway and sat down on the edge of the gunrest  watching him still as <eos>
<sos> he propped his mirror on the parapet  dipped the brush in the bowl and <eos>
<sos> lathered cheeks and neck  <eos>
<sos> buck mulligan is gay voice went on  <eos>
<sos>  my name is absurd too  malachi mulligan  two dactyls  but it has a <eos>
<sos> hellenic ring  has not it  tripping and sunny like the buck himself  we <eos>
<sos> must go to athens  will you come if i can get the aunt to fork out <eos>
<sos> twenty quid  <eos>
<sos> he laid the brush aside and  laughing with delight  cried  <eos>
<sos>  will he come  the jejune jesuit  <eos>
<sos> ceasing  he began to shave with care  <eos>
<sos>  tell me  mulligan  stephen said quietly  <eos>
<sos>  yes  my love  <eos>
<sos>  how long is haines going to stay in this tower  <eos>
<sos> buck mulligan showed a shaven cheek over his right shoulder  <eos>
<sos>  god  is not he dreadful  he said frankly  a ponderous saxon  he thinks <eos>
<sos> you re not a gentleman  god  these bloody english  bursting with money <eos>
<sos> and indigestion  because he comes from oxford  you know  dedalus  you <eos>
<sos> have the real oxford manner  he ca not make you out  o  my name for you <eos>
<sos> is the best  kinch  the knife blade  <eos>
<sos> he shaved warily over his chin  <eos>
<sos>  he was raving all night about a black panther  stephen said  where is <eos>
<sos> his guncase  <eos>
<sos>  a woful lunatic  mulligan said  were you in a funk  <eos>
<sos>  i was  stephen said with energy and growing fear  out here in the dark <eos>
<sos> with a man i do not know raving and moaning to himself about shooting a <eos>
<sos> black panther  you saved men from drowning  i am not a hero  however  if <eos>
<sos> he stays on here i am off  <eos>
<sos> buck mulligan frowned at the lather on his razorblade  he hopped down <eos>
<sos> from his perch and began to search his trouser pockets hastily  <eos>
<sos>  scutter  he cried thickly  <eos>
<sos> he came over to the gunrest and  thrusting a hand into stephen is upper <eos>
<sos> pocket  said  <eos>
<sos>  lend us a loan of your noserag to wipe my razor  <eos>
<sos> stephen suffered him to pull out and hold up on show by its corner a <eos>
<sos> dirty crumpled handkerchief  buck mulligan wiped the razorblade neatly  <eos>
<sos> then  gazing over the handkerchief  he said  <eos>
<sos>  the bard is noserag  a new art colour for our irish poets  snotgreen  <eos>
<sos> you can almost taste it  ca not you  <eos>
<sos> he mounted to the parapet again and gazed out over dublin bay  his fair <eos>
<sos> oakpale hair stirring slightly  <eos>
<sos>  god  he said quietly  is not the sea what algy calls it  a great sweet <eos>
<sos> mother  the snotgreen sea  the scrotumtightening sea  _epi oinopa <eos>
<sos> ponton_  ah  dedalus  the greeks  i must teach you  you must read them <eos>
<sos> in the original  thalatta  thalatta  she is our great sweet mother  <eos>
<sos> come and look  <eos>
<sos> stephen stood up and went over to the parapet  leaning on it he looked <eos>
<sos> down on the water and on the mailboat clearing the harbourmouth of <eos>
<sos> kingstown  <eos>
<sos>  our mighty mother  buck mulligan said  <eos>
<sos> he turned abruptly his grey searching eyes from the sea to stephen is <eos>
<sos> face  <eos>
<sos>  the aunt thinks you killed your mother  he said  that is why she wo not <eos>
<sos> let me have anything to do with you  <eos>
<sos>  someone killed her  stephen said gloomily  <eos>
<sos>  you could have knelt down  damn it  kinch  when your dying mother <eos>
<sos> asked you  buck mulligan said  i am hyperborean as much as you  but to <eos>
<sos> think of your mother begging you with her last breath to kneel down and <eos>
<sos> pray for her  and you refused  there is something sinister in you     <eos>
<sos> he broke off and lathered again lightly his farther cheek  a tolerant <eos>
<sos> smile curled his lips  <eos>
<sos>  but a lovely mummer  he murmured to himself  kinch  the loveliest <eos>
<sos> mummer of them all  <eos>
<sos> he shaved evenly and with care  in silence  seriously  <eos>
<sos> stephen  an elbow rested on the jagged granite  leaned his palm against <eos>
<sos> his brow and gazed at the fraying edge of his shiny black coat sleeve  <eos>
<sos> pain  that was not yet the pain of love  fretted his heart  silently  <eos>
<sos> in a dream she had come to him after her death  her wasted body within <eos>
<sos> its loose brown graveclothes giving off an odour of wax and rosewood  <eos>
<sos> her breath  that had bent upon him  mute  reproachful  a faint odour of <eos>
<sos> wetted ashes  across the threadbare cuffedge he saw the sea hailed as a <eos>
<sos> great sweet mother by the wellfed voice beside him  the ring of bay and <eos>
<sos> skyline held a dull green mass of liquid  a bowl of white china had <eos>
<sos> stood beside her deathbed holding the green sluggish bile which she had <eos>
<sos> torn up from her rotting liver by fits of loud groaning vomiting  <eos>
<sos> buck mulligan wiped again his razorblade  <eos>
<sos>  ah  poor dogsbody  he said in a kind voice  i must give you a shirt <eos>
<sos> and a few noserags  how are the secondhand breeks  <eos>
<sos>  they fit well enough  stephen answered  <eos>
<sos> buck mulligan attacked the hollow beneath his underlip  <eos>
<sos>  the mockery of it  he said contentedly  secondleg they should be  god <eos>
<sos> knows what poxy bowsy left them off  i have a lovely pair with a hair <eos>
<sos> stripe  grey  you ll look spiffing in them  i am not joking  kinch  you <eos>
<sos> look damn well when you re dressed  <eos>
<sos>  thanks  stephen said  i ca not wear them if they are grey  <eos>
<sos>  he ca not wear them  buck mulligan told his face in the mirror  <eos>
<sos> etiquette is etiquette  he kills his mother but he ca not wear grey <eos>
<sos> trousers  <eos>
<sos> he folded his razor neatly and with stroking palps of fingers felt the <eos>
<sos> smooth skin  <eos>
<sos> stephen turned his gaze from the sea and to the plump face with its <eos>
<sos> smokeblue mobile eyes  <eos>
<sos>  that fellow i was with in the ship last night  said buck mulligan  <eos>
<sos> says you have g  p  i  he is up in dottyville with connolly norman  <eos>
<sos> general paralysis of the insane  <eos>
<sos> he swept the mirror a half circle in the air to flash the tidings <eos>
<sos> abroad in sunlight now radiant on the sea  his curling shaven lips <eos>
<sos> laughed and the edges of his white glittering teeth  laughter seized <eos>
<sos> all his strong wellknit trunk  <eos>
<sos>  look at yourself  he said  you dreadful bard  <eos>
<sos> stephen bent forward and peered at the mirror held out to him  cleft by <eos>
<sos> a crooked crack  hair on end  as he and others see me  who chose this <eos>
<sos> face for me  this dogsbody to rid of vermin  it asks me too  <eos>
<sos>  i pinched it out of the skivvy is room  buck mulligan said  it does her <eos>
<sos> all right  the aunt always keeps plainlooking servants for malachi  <eos>
<sos> lead him not into temptation  and her name is ursula  <eos>
<sos> laughing again  he brought the mirror away from stephen is peering eyes  <eos>
<sos>  the rage of caliban at not seeing his face in a mirror  he said  if <eos>
<sos> wilde were only alive to see you  <eos>
<sos> drawing back and pointing  stephen said with bitterness  <eos>
<sos>  it is a symbol of irish art  the cracked lookingglass of a servant  <eos>
<sos> buck mulligan suddenly linked his arm in stephen is and walked with him <eos>
<sos> round the tower  his razor and mirror clacking in the pocket where he <eos>
<sos> had thrust them  <eos>
<sos>  it is not fair to tease you like that  kinch  is it  he said kindly  <eos>
<sos> god knows you have more spirit than any of them  <eos>
<sos> parried again  he fears the lancet of my art as i fear that of his  the <eos>
<sos> cold steel pen  <eos>
<sos>  cracked lookingglass of a servant  tell that to the oxy chap <eos>
<sos> downstairs and touch him for a guinea  he is stinking with money and <eos>
<sos> thinks you re not a gentleman  his old fellow made his tin by selling <eos>
<sos> jalap to zulus or some bloody swindle or other  god  kinch  if you and <eos>
<sos> i could only work together we might do something for the island  <eos>
<sos> hellenise it  <eos>
<sos> cranly is arm  his arm  <eos>
<sos>  and to think of your having to beg from these swine  i am the only one <eos>
<sos> that knows what you are  why do not you trust me more  what have you up <eos>
<sos> your nose against me  is it haines  if he makes any noise here i ll <eos>
<sos> bring down seymour and we ll give him a ragging worse than they gave <eos>
<sos> clive kempthorpe  <eos>
<sos> young shouts of moneyed voices in clive kempthorpe is rooms  palefaces  <eos>
<sos> they hold their ribs with laughter  one clasping another  o  i shall <eos>
<sos> expire  break the news to her gently  aubrey  i shall die  with slit <eos>
<sos> ribbons of his shirt whipping the air he hops and hobbles round the <eos>
<sos> table  with trousers down at heels  chased by ades of magdalen with the <eos>
<sos> tailor is shears  a scared calf is face gilded with marmalade  i do not <eos>
<sos> want to be debagged  do not you play the giddy ox with me  <eos>
<sos> shouts from the open window startling evening in the quadrangle  a deaf <eos>
<sos> gardener  aproned  masked with matthew arnold is face  pushes his mower <eos>
<sos> on the sombre lawn watching narrowly the dancing motes of grasshalms  <eos>
<sos> to ourselves    new paganism    omphalos  <eos>
<sos>  let him stay  stephen said  there is nothing wrong with him except at <eos>
<sos> night  <eos>
<sos>  then what is it  buck mulligan asked impatiently  cough it up  i am <eos>
<sos> quite frank with you  what have you against me now  <eos>
<sos> they halted  looking towards the blunt cape of bray head that lay on <eos>
<sos> the water like the snout of a sleeping whale  stephen freed his arm <eos>
<sos> quietly  <eos>
<sos>  do you wish me to tell you  he asked  <eos>
<sos>  yes  what is it  buck mulligan answered  i do not remember anything  <eos>
<sos> he looked in stephen is face as he spoke  a light wind passed his brow  <eos>
<sos> fanning softly his fair uncombed hair and stirring silver points of <eos>
<sos> anxiety in his eyes  <eos>
<sos> stephen  depressed by his own voice  said  <eos>
<sos>  do you remember the first day i went to your house after my mother is <eos>
<sos> death  <eos>
<sos> buck mulligan frowned quickly and said  <eos>
<sos>  what  where  i ca not remember anything  i remember only ideas and <eos>
<sos> sensations  why  what happened in the name of god  <eos>
<sos>  you were making tea  stephen said  and went across the landing to get <eos>
<sos> more hot water  your mother and some visitor came out of the <eos>
<sos> drawingroom  she asked you who was in your room  <eos>
<sos>  yes  buck mulligan said  what did i say  i forget  <eos>
<sos>  you said  stephen answered  _o  it is only dedalus whose mother is <eos>
<sos> beastly dead _ <eos>
<sos> a flush which made him seem younger and more engaging rose to buck <eos>
<sos> mulligan is cheek  <eos>
<sos>  did i say that  he asked  well  what harm is that  <eos>
<sos> he shook his constraint from him nervously  <eos>
<sos>  and what is death  he asked  your mother is or yours or my own  you saw <eos>
<sos> only your mother die  i see them pop off every day in the mater and <eos>
<sos> richmond and cut up into tripes in the dissectingroom  it is a beastly <eos>
<sos> thing and nothing else  it simply does not matter  you would not kneel <eos>
<sos> down to pray for your mother on her deathbed when she asked you  why  <eos>
<sos> because you have the cursed jesuit strain in you  only it is injected <eos>
<sos> the wrong way  to me it is all a mockery and beastly  her cerebral lobes <eos>
<sos> are not functioning  she calls the doctor sir peter teazle and picks <eos>
<sos> buttercups off the quilt  humour her till it is over  you crossed her <eos>
<sos> last wish in death and yet you sulk with me because i do not whinge like <eos>
<sos> some hired mute from lalouette is  absurd  i suppose i did say it  i <eos>
<sos> did not mean to offend the memory of your mother  <eos>
<sos> he had spoken himself into boldness  stephen  shielding the gaping <eos>
<sos> wounds which the words had left in his heart  said very coldly  <eos>
<sos>  i am not thinking of the offence to my mother  <eos>
<sos>  of what then  buck mulligan asked  <eos>
<sos>  of the offence to me  stephen answered  <eos>
<sos> buck mulligan swung round on his heel  <eos>
<sos>  o  an impossible person  he exclaimed  <eos>
<sos> he walked off quickly round the parapet  stephen stood at his post  <eos>
<sos> gazing over the calm sea towards the headland  sea and headland now <eos>
<sos> grew dim  pulses were beating in his eyes  veiling their sight  and he <eos>
<sos> felt the fever of his cheeks  <eos>
<sos> a voice within the tower called loudly  <eos>
<sos>  are you up there  mulligan  <eos>
<sos>  i am coming  buck mulligan answered  <eos>
<sos> he turned towards stephen and said  <eos>
<sos>  look at the sea  what does it care about offences  chuck loyola  <eos>
<sos> kinch  and come on down  the sassenach wants his morning rashers  <eos>
<sos> his head halted again for a moment at the top of the staircase  level <eos>
<sos> with the roof  <eos>
<sos>  do not mope over it all day  he said  i am inconsequent  give up the <eos>
<sos> moody brooding  <eos>
<sos> his head vanished but the drone of his descending voice boomed out of <eos>
<sos> the stairhead  <eos>
<sos> and no more turn aside and brood <eos>
<sos> upon love is bitter mystery <eos>
<sos> for fergus rules the brazen cars  <eos>
<sos> woodshadows floated silently by through the morning peace from the <eos>
<sos> stairhead seaward where he gazed  inshore and farther out the mirror of <eos>
<sos> water whitened  spurned by lightshod hurrying feet  white breast of the <eos>
<sos> dim sea  the twining stresses  two by two  a hand plucking the <eos>
<sos> harpstrings  merging their twining chords  wavewhite wedded words <eos>
<sos> shimmering on the dim tide  <eos>
<sos> a cloud began to cover the sun slowly  wholly  shadowing the bay in <eos>
<sos> deeper green  it lay beneath him  a bowl of bitter waters  fergus  <eos>
<sos> song  i sang it alone in the house  holding down the long dark chords  <eos>
<sos> her door was open  she wanted to hear my music  silent with awe and <eos>
<sos> pity i went to her bedside  she was crying in her wretched bed  for <eos>
<sos> those words  stephen  love is bitter mystery  <eos>
<sos> where now  <eos>
<sos> her secrets  old featherfans  tasselled dancecards  powdered with musk  <eos>
<sos> a gaud of amber beads in her locked drawer  a birdcage hung in the <eos>
<sos> sunny window of her house when she was a girl  she heard old royce sing <eos>
<sos> in the pantomime of turko the terrible and laughed with others when he <eos>
<sos> sang  <eos>
<sos> i am the boy <eos>
<sos> that can enjoy <eos>
<sos> invisibility  <eos>
<sos> phantasmal mirth  folded away  muskperfumed  <eos>
<sos> and no more turn aside and brood  <eos>
<sos> folded away in the memory of nature with her toys  memories beset his <eos>
<sos> brooding brain  her glass of water from the kitchen tap when she had <eos>
<sos> approached the sacrament  a cored apple  filled with brown sugar  <eos>
<sos> roasting for her at the hob on a dark autumn evening  her shapely <eos>
<sos> fingernails reddened by the blood of squashed lice from the children is <eos>
<sos> shirts  <eos>
<sos> in a dream  silently  she had come to him  her wasted body within its <eos>
<sos> loose graveclothes giving off an odour of wax and rosewood  her breath  <eos>
<sos> bent over him with mute secret words  a faint odour of wetted ashes  <eos>
<sos> her glazing eyes  staring out of death  to shake and bend my soul  on <eos>
<sos> me alone  the ghostcandle to light her agony  ghostly light on the <eos>
<sos> tortured face  her hoarse loud breath rattling in horror  while all <eos>
<sos> prayed on their knees  her eyes on me to strike me down  _liliata <eos>
<sos> rutilantium te confessorum turma circumdet  iubilantium te virginum <eos>
<sos> chorus excipiat _ <eos>
<sos> ghoul  chewer of corpses  <eos>
<sos> no  mother  let me be and let me live  <eos>
<sos>  kinch ahoy  <eos>

<sos> staircase  calling again  stephen  still trembling at his soul is cry  <eos>
<sos> heard warm running sunlight and in the air behind him friendly words  <eos>
<sos>  dedalus  come down  like a good mosey  breakfast is ready  haines is <eos>
<sos> apologising for waking us last night  it is all right  <eos>

<sos>  i get paid this morning  stephen said  <eos>
<sos>  the school kip  buck mulligan said  how much  four quid  lend us one  <eos>
<sos>  if you want it  stephen said  <eos>
<sos>  four shining sovereigns  buck mulligan cried with delight  we ll have <eos>
<sos> a glorious drunk to astonish the druidy druids  four omnipotent <eos>
<sos> sovereigns  <eos>
<sos> he flung up his hands and tramped down the stone stairs  singing out of <eos>
<sos> tune with a cockney accent  <eos>
<sos> o  wo not we have a merry time  <eos>
<sos> drinking whisky  beer and wine  <eos>
<sos> on coronation  <eos>
<sos> coronation day  <eos>
<sos> o  wo not we have a merry time <eos>
<sos> on coronation day  <eos>
<sos> warm sunshine merrying over the sea  the nickel shavingbowl shone  <eos>
<sos> forgotten  on the parapet  why should i bring it down  or leave it <eos>
<sos> there all day  forgotten friendship  <eos>
<sos> he went over to it  held it in his hands awhile  feeling its coolness  <eos>
<sos> smelling the clammy slaver of the lather in which the brush was stuck  <eos>
<sos> so i carried the boat of incense then at clongowes  i am another now <eos>
<sos> and yet the same  a servant too  a server of a servant  <eos>
<sos> in the gloomy domed livingroom of the tower buck mulligan is gowned form <eos>
<sos> moved briskly to and fro about the hearth  hiding and revealing its <eos>
<sos> yellow glow  two shafts of soft daylight fell across the flagged floor <eos>
<sos> from the high barbacans  and at the meeting of their rays a cloud of <eos>
<sos> coalsmoke and fumes of fried grease floated  turning  <eos>
<sos>  we ll be choked  buck mulligan said  haines  open that door  will you  <eos>
<sos> stephen laid the shavingbowl on the locker  a tall figure rose from the <eos>
<sos> hammock where it had been sitting  went to the doorway and pulled open <eos>
<sos> the inner doors  <eos>
<sos>  have you the key  a voice asked  <eos>
<sos>  dedalus has it  buck mulligan said  janey mack  i am choked  <eos>
<sos> he howled  without looking up from the fire  <eos>
<sos>  kinch  <eos>
<sos>  it is in the lock  stephen said  coming forward  <eos>
<sos> the key scraped round harshly twice and  when the heavy door had been <eos>
<sos> set ajar  welcome light and bright air entered  haines stood at the <eos>
<sos> doorway  looking out  stephen haled his upended valise to the table and <eos>
<sos> sat down to wait  buck mulligan tossed the fry on to the dish beside <eos>
<sos> him  then he carried the dish and a large teapot over to the table  set <eos>
<sos> them down heavily and sighed with relief  <eos>
<sos>  i am melting  he said  as the candle remarked when    but  hush  not a <eos>
<sos> word more on that subject  kinch  wake up  bread  butter  honey  <eos>
<sos> haines  come in  the grub is ready  bless us  o lord  and these thy <eos>
<sos> gifts  where is the sugar  o  jay  there is no milk  <eos>
<sos> stephen fetched the loaf and the pot of honey and the buttercooler from <eos>
<sos> the locker  buck mulligan sat down in a sudden pet  <eos>
<sos>  what sort of a kip is this  he said  i told her to come after eight  <eos>
<sos>  we can drink it black  stephen said thirstily  there is a lemon in the <eos>
<sos> locker  <eos>
<sos>  o  damn you and your paris fads  buck mulligan said  i want sandycove <eos>
<sos> milk  <eos>
<sos> haines came in from the doorway and said quietly  <eos>
<sos>  that woman is coming up with the milk  <eos>

<sos> chair  sit down  pour out the tea there  the sugar is in the bag  here  <eos>
<sos> i ca not go fumbling at the damned eggs  <eos>
<sos> he hacked through the fry on the dish and slapped it out on three <eos>
<sos> plates  saying  <eos>
<sos>  in nomine patris et filii et spiritus sancti  <eos>
<sos> haines sat down to pour out the tea  <eos>
<sos>  i am giving you two lumps each  he said  but  i say  mulligan  you do <eos>
<sos> make strong tea  do not you  <eos>
<sos> buck mulligan  hewing thick slices from the loaf  said in an old <eos>
<sos> woman is wheedling voice  <eos>
<sos>  when i makes tea i makes tea  as old mother grogan said  and when i <eos>
<sos> makes water i makes water  <eos>
<sos>  by jove  it is tea  haines said  <eos>
<sos> buck mulligan went on hewing and wheedling  <eos>

<sos> send you do not make them in the one pot _ <eos>
<sos> he lunged towards his messmates in turn a thick slice of bread  impaled <eos>
<sos> on his knife  <eos>
<sos>  that is folk  he said very earnestly  for your book  haines  five lines <eos>
<sos> of text and ten pages of notes about the folk and the fishgods of <eos>
<sos> dundrum  printed by the weird sisters in the year of the big wind  <eos>

<sos>  i fancy  stephen said as he ate  it did not exist in or out of the <eos>
<sos> mabinogion  mother grogan was  one imagines  a kinswoman of mary ann  <eos>
<sos> buck mulligan is face smiled with delight  <eos>
<sos>  charming  he said in a finical sweet voice  showing his white teeth <eos>
<sos> and blinking his eyes pleasantly  do you think she was  quite charming  <eos>

<sos> _ for old mary ann <eos>
<sos> she does not care a damn  <eos>
<sos> but  hising up her petticoats   _ <eos>
<sos> he crammed his mouth with fry and munched and droned  <eos>
<sos> the doorway was darkened by an entering form  <eos>
<sos>  the milk  sir  <eos>
<sos>  come in  ma am  mulligan said  kinch  get the jug  <eos>
<sos> an old woman came forward and stood by stephen is elbow  <eos>
<sos>  that is a lovely morning  sir  she said  glory be to god  <eos>
<sos>  to whom  mulligan said  glancing at her  ah  to be sure  <eos>
<sos> stephen reached back and took the milkjug from the locker  <eos>
<sos>  the islanders  mulligan said to haines casually  speak frequently of <eos>
<sos> the collector of prepuces  <eos>
<sos>  how much  sir  asked the old woman  <eos>
<sos>  a quart  stephen said  <eos>
<sos> he watched her pour into the measure and thence into the jug rich white <eos>
<sos> milk  not hers  old shrunken paps  she poured again a measureful and a <eos>
<sos> tilly  old and secret she had entered from a morning world  maybe a <eos>
<sos> messenger  she praised the goodness of the milk  pouring it out  <eos>
<sos> crouching by a patient cow at daybreak in the lush field  a witch on <eos>
<sos> her toadstool  her wrinkled fingers quick at the squirting dugs  they <eos>
<sos> lowed about her whom they knew  dewsilky cattle  silk of the kine and <eos>
<sos> poor old woman  names given her in old times  a wandering crone  lowly <eos>
<sos> form of an immortal serving her conqueror and her gay betrayer  their <eos>
<sos> common cuckquean  a messenger from the secret morning  to serve or to <eos>
<sos> upbraid  whether he could not tell  but scorned to beg her favour  <eos>
<sos>  it is indeed  ma am  buck mulligan said  pouring milk into their cups  <eos>
<sos>  taste it  sir  she said  <eos>
<sos> he drank at her bidding  <eos>
<sos>  if we could live on good food like that  he said to her somewhat <eos>
<sos> loudly  we would not have the country full of rotten teeth and rotten <eos>
<sos> guts  living in a bogswamp  eating cheap food and the streets paved <eos>
<sos> with dust  horsedung and consumptives  spits  <eos>
<sos>  are you a medical student  sir  the old woman asked  <eos>
<sos>  i am  ma am  buck mulligan answered  <eos>
<sos>  look at that now  she said  <eos>
<sos> stephen listened in scornful silence  she bows her old head to a voice <eos>
<sos> that speaks to her loudly  her bonesetter  her medicineman  me she <eos>
<sos> slights  to the voice that will shrive and oil for the grave all there <eos>
<sos> is of her but her woman is unclean loins  of man is flesh made not in <eos>
<sos> god is likeness  the serpent is prey  and to the loud voice that now bids <eos>
<sos> her be silent with wondering unsteady eyes  <eos>
<sos>  do you understand what he says  stephen asked her  <eos>
<sos>  is it french you are talking  sir  the old woman said to haines  <eos>
<sos> haines spoke to her again a longer speech  confidently  <eos>

<sos>  i thought it was irish  she said  by the sound of it  are you from the <eos>
<sos> west  sir  <eos>

<sos> shilling and one and two is two and two  sir  <eos>

<sos> his trouser pockets  <eos>

<sos> his fingers and cried  <eos>
<sos>  a miracle  <eos>
<sos> he passed it along the table towards the old woman  saying  <eos>
<sos>  ask nothing more of me  sweet  all i can give you i give  <eos>

<sos>  we ll owe twopence  he said  <eos>

<sos> _ heart of my heart  were it more  <eos>
<sos> more would be laid at your feet _ <eos>
<sos> he turned to stephen and said  <eos>
<sos>  seriously  dedalus  i am stony  hurry out to your school kip and bring <eos>

<sos> trickle over a slice of the loaf  <eos>

<sos> loose collar of his tennis shirt spoke  <eos>

<sos> conscience  yet here is a spot  <eos>
<sos>  that one about the cracked lookingglass of a servant being the symbol <eos>

<sos> the hammock  said  <eos>

<sos> boots  contradiction  do i contradict myself  very well then  i <eos>

<sos> his talking hands  <eos>

<sos> with grave words and gait  saying  wellnigh with sorrow  <eos>
<sos>  and going forth he met butterly  <eos>
<sos> stephen  taking his ashplant from its leaningplace  followed them out <eos>
<sos> and  as they went down the ladder  pulled to the slow iron door and <eos>
<sos> locked it  he put the huge key in his inner pocket  <eos>

<sos>  did you bring the key  <eos>
<sos>  i have it  stephen said  preceding them  <eos>
<sos> he walked on  behind him he heard buck mulligan club with his heavy <eos>
<sos> bathtowel the leader shoots of ferns or grasses  <eos>
<sos>  down  sir  how dare you  sir  <eos>
<sos> haines asked  <eos>
<sos>  do you pay rent for this tower  <eos>

<sos>  rather bleak in wintertime  i should say  martello you call it  <eos>
<sos>  billy pitt had them built  buck mulligan said  when the french were on <eos>
<sos> the sea  but ours is the omphalos  <eos>

<sos>  no  no  buck mulligan shouted in pain  i am not equal to thomas aquinas <eos>

<sos> primrose waistcoat  <eos>

<sos>  it has waited so long  stephen said listlessly  it can wait longer  <eos>

<sos> it is quite simple  he proves by algebra that hamlet is grandson is <eos>
<sos> shakespeare is grandfather and that he himself is the ghost of his own <eos>
<sos> father  <eos>
<sos>  what  haines said  beginning to point at stephen  he himself  <eos>
<sos> buck mulligan slung his towel stolewise round his neck and  bending in <eos>
<sos> loose laughter  said to stephen is ear  <eos>
<sos>  o  shade of kinch the elder  japhet in search of a father  <eos>
<sos>  we re always tired in the morning  stephen said to haines  and it is <eos>
<sos> rather long to tell  <eos>
<sos> buck mulligan  walking forward again  raised his hands  <eos>
<sos>  the sacred pint alone can unbind the tongue of dedalus  he said  <eos>
<sos>  i mean to say  haines explained to stephen as they followed  this <eos>
<sos> tower and these cliffs here remind me somehow of elsinore  _that <eos>
<sos> beetles o er his base into the sea _ is not it  <eos>
<sos> buck mulligan turned suddenly for an instant towards stephen but did <eos>
<sos> not speak  in the bright silent instant stephen saw his own image in <eos>
<sos> cheap dusty mourning between their gay attires  <eos>
<sos>  it is a wonderful tale  haines said  bringing them to halt again  <eos>
<sos> eyes  pale as the sea the wind had freshened  paler  firm and prudent  <eos>
<sos> the seas  ruler  he gazed southward over the bay  empty save for the <eos>
<sos> smokeplume of the mailboat vague on the bright skyline and a sail <eos>
<sos> tacking by the muglins  <eos>
<sos>  i read a theological interpretation of it somewhere  he said bemused  <eos>
<sos> the father and the son idea  the son striving to be atoned with the <eos>
<sos> father  <eos>
<sos> buck mulligan at once put on a blithe broadly smiling face  he looked <eos>
<sos> at them  his wellshaped mouth open happily  his eyes  from which he had <eos>
<sos> suddenly withdrawn all shrewd sense  blinking with mad gaiety  he moved <eos>
<sos> a doll is head to and fro  the brims of his panama hat quivering  and <eos>
<sos> began to chant in a quiet happy foolish voice  <eos>
<sos> _ i am the queerest young fellow that ever you heard  <eos>
<sos> my mother is a jew  my father is a bird  <eos>
<sos> with joseph the joiner i cannot agree  <eos>
<sos> so here is to disciples and calvary _ <eos>
<sos> he held up a forefinger of warning  <eos>
<sos> _ if anyone thinks that i am not divine <eos>
<sos> he ll get no free drinks when i am making the wine <eos>
<sos> but have to drink water and wish it were plain <eos>
<sos> that i make when the wine becomes water again _ <eos>
<sos> he tugged swiftly at stephen is ashplant in farewell and  running <eos>
<sos> forward to a brow of the cliff  fluttered his hands at his sides like <eos>
<sos> fins or wings of one about to rise in the air  and chanted  <eos>
<sos> _ goodbye  now  goodbye  write down all i said <eos>
<sos> and tell tom  dick and harry i rose from the dead  <eos>
<sos> what is bred in the bone cannot fail me to fly <eos>
<sos> and olivet is breezy    goodbye  now  goodbye _ <eos>
<sos> he capered before them down towards the fortyfoot hole  fluttering his <eos>
<sos> winglike hands  leaping nimbly  mercury is hat quivering in the fresh <eos>
<sos> wind that bore back to them his brief birdsweet cries  <eos>
<sos> haines  who had been laughing guardedly  walked on beside stephen and <eos>
<sos> said  <eos>
<sos>  we ought not to laugh  i suppose  he is rather blasphemous  i am not a <eos>
<sos> believer myself  that is to say  still his gaiety takes the harm out of <eos>
<sos> it somehow  does not it  what did he call it  joseph the joiner  <eos>
<sos>  the ballad of joking jesus  stephen answered  <eos>
<sos>  o  haines said  you have heard it before  <eos>
<sos>  three times a day  after meals  stephen said drily  <eos>
<sos>  you re not a believer  are you  haines asked  i mean  a believer in <eos>
<sos> the narrow sense of the word  creation from nothing and miracles and a <eos>
<sos> personal god  <eos>
<sos>  there is only one sense of the word  it seems to me  stephen said  <eos>
<sos> haines stopped to take out a smooth silver case in which twinkled a <eos>
<sos> green stone  he sprang it open with his thumb and offered it  <eos>
<sos>  thank you  stephen said  taking a cigarette  <eos>
<sos> haines helped himself and snapped the case to  he put it back in his <eos>
<sos> sidepocket and took from his waistcoatpocket a nickel tinderbox  sprang <eos>
<sos> it open too  and  having lit his cigarette  held the flaming spunk <eos>
<sos> towards stephen in the shell of his hands  <eos>
<sos>  yes  of course  he said  as they went on again  either you believe or <eos>
<sos> you do not  is not it  personally i could not stomach that idea of a <eos>
<sos> personal god  you do not stand for that  i suppose  <eos>
<sos>  you behold in me  stephen said with grim displeasure  a horrible <eos>
<sos> example of free thought  <eos>
<sos> he walked on  waiting to be spoken to  trailing his ashplant by his <eos>
<sos> side  its ferrule followed lightly on the path  squealing at his heels  <eos>
<sos> my familiar  after me  calling  steeeeeeeeeeeephen  a wavering line <eos>
<sos> along the path  they will walk on it tonight  coming here in the dark  <eos>
<sos> he wants that key  it is mine  i paid the rent  now i eat his salt <eos>
<sos> bread  give him the key too  all  he will ask for it  that was in his <eos>
<sos> eyes  <eos>
<sos>  after all  haines began    <eos>
<sos> stephen turned and saw that the cold gaze which had measured him was <eos>
<sos> not all unkind  <eos>
<sos>  after all  i should think you are able to free yourself  you are your <eos>
<sos> own master  it seems to me  <eos>
<sos>  i am a servant of two masters  stephen said  an english and an <eos>
<sos> italian  <eos>
<sos>  italian  haines said  <eos>
<sos> a crazy queen  old and jealous  kneel down before me  <eos>
<sos>  and a third  stephen said  there is who wants me for odd jobs  <eos>
<sos>  italian  haines said again  what do you mean  <eos>
<sos>  the imperial british state  stephen answered  his colour rising  and <eos>
<sos> the holy roman catholic and apostolic church  <eos>
<sos> haines detached from his underlip some fibres of tobacco before he <eos>
<sos> spoke  <eos>

<sos> shillings and no pence sterling  and the said nonperishable goods shall <eos>
<sos> not be pawned or pledged or sold or otherwise alienated by the said <eos>
<sos> purchaser but shall be and remain and be held to be the sole and <eos>
<sos> exclusive property of the said vendor to be disposed of at his good <eos>
<sos> will and pleasure until the said amount shall have been duly paid by <eos>
<sos> the said purchaser to the said vendor in the manner herein set forth as <eos>

<sos> his eyes glowered furiously  as he awaited the fatal signal he tested <eos>
<sos> the edge of his horrible weapon by honing it upon his brawny forearm or <eos>
<sos> decapitated in rapid succession a flock of sheep which had been <eos>
<sos> provided by the admirers of his fell but necessary office  on a <eos>
<sos> handsome mahogany table near him were neatly arranged the quartering <eos>
<sos> knife  the various finely tempered disembowelling appliances  specially <eos>
<sos> supplied by the worldfamous firm of cutlers  messrs john round and <eos>
<sos> sons  sheffield   a terra cotta saucepan for the reception of the <eos>
<sos> duodenum  colon  blind intestine and appendix etc when successfully <eos>
<sos> extracted and two commodious milkjugs destined to receive the most <eos>
<sos> precious blood of the most precious victim  the housesteward of the <eos>
<sos> amalgamated cats  and dogs  home was in attendance to convey these <eos>
<sos> vessels when replenished to that beneficent institution  quite an <eos>
<sos> excellent repast consisting of rashers and eggs  fried steak and <eos>
<sos> onions  done to a nicety  delicious hot breakfast rolls and <eos>
<sos> invigorating tea had been considerately provided by the authorities for <eos>
<sos> the consumption of the central figure of the tragedy who was in capital <eos>
<sos> spirits when prepared for death and evinced the keenest interest in the <eos>
<sos> proceedings from beginning to end but he  with an abnegation rare in <eos>
<sos> these our times  rose nobly to the occasion and expressed the dying <eos>
<sos> wish  immediately acceded to  that the meal should be divided in <eos>
<sos> aliquot parts among the members of the sick and indigent roomkeepers  <eos>
<sos> association as a token of his regard and esteem  the nec and _non <eos>
<sos> plus ultra_ of emotion were reached when the blushing bride elect burst <eos>
<sos> her way through the serried ranks of the bystanders and flung herself <eos>
<sos> upon the muscular bosom of him who was about to be launched into <eos>
<sos> eternity for her sake  the hero folded her willowy form in a loving <eos>
<sos> embrace murmuring fondly sheila  my own  encouraged by this use of <eos>
<sos> her christian name she kissed passionately all the various suitable <eos>
<sos> areas of his person which the decencies of prison garb permitted her <eos>
<sos> ardour to reach  she swore to him as they mingled the salt streams of <eos>
<sos> their tears that she would ever cherish his memory  that she would <eos>
<sos> never forget her hero boy who went to his death with a song on his lips <eos>
<sos> as if he were but going to a hurling match in clonturk park  she <eos>
<sos> brought back to his recollection the happy days of blissful childhood <eos>
<sos> together on the banks of anna liffey when they had indulged in the <eos>
<sos> innocent pastimes of the young and  oblivious of the dreadful present  <eos>
<sos> they both laughed heartily  all the spectators  including the venerable <eos>
<sos> pastor  joining in the general merriment  that monster audience simply <eos>
<sos> rocked with delight  but anon they were overcome with grief and clasped <eos>
<sos> their hands for the last time  a fresh torrent of tears burst from <eos>
<sos> their lachrymal ducts and the vast concourse of people  touched to the <eos>

<sos> the summer evening had begun to fold the world in its mysterious <eos>
<sos> embrace  far away in the west the sun was setting and the last glow of <eos>

<sos> that the traveller had said thing that was false for his subtility  but <eos>
<sos> the learningknight would not hear say nay nor do her mandement ne have <eos>
<sos> him in aught contrarious to his list and he said how it was a <eos>
<sos> marvellous castle  and the traveller leopold went into the castle for <eos>
<sos> to rest him for a space being sore of limb after many marches <eos>
<sos> environing in divers lands and sometime venery  <eos>
<sos> and in the castle was set a board that was of the birchwood of finlandy <eos>
<sos> and it was upheld by four dwarfmen of that country but they durst not <eos>
<sos> move more for enchantment  and on this board were frightful swords and <eos>
<sos> knives that are made in a great cavern by swinking demons out of white <eos>
<sos> flames that they fix then in the horns of buffalos and stags that there <eos>
<sos> abound marvellously  and there were vessels that are wrought by magic <eos>
<sos> of mahound out of seasand and the air by a warlock with his breath that <eos>
<sos> he blases in to them like to bubbles  and full fair cheer and rich was <eos>
<sos> on the board that no wight could devise a fuller ne richer  and there <eos>
<sos> was a vat of silver that was moved by craft to open in the which lay <eos>
<sos> strange fishes withouten heads though misbelieving men nie that this be <eos>
<sos> possible thing without they see it natheless they are so  and these <eos>
<sos> fishes lie in an oily water brought there from portugal land because of <eos>
<sos> the fatness that therein is like to the juices of the olivepress  and <eos>
<sos> also it was a marvel to see in that castle how by magic they make a <eos>
<sos> compost out of fecund wheatkidneys out of chaldee that by aid of <eos>
<sos> certain angry spirits that they do in to it swells up wondrously like <eos>
<sos> to a vast mountain  and they teach the serpents there to entwine <eos>
<sos> themselves up on long sticks out of the ground and of the scales of <eos>
<sos> these serpents they brew out a brewage like to mead  <eos>
<sos> and the learning knight let pour for childe leopold a draught and halp <eos>
<sos> thereto the while all they that were there drank every each  and childe <eos>
<sos> leopold did up his beaver for to pleasure him and took apertly somewhat <eos>
<sos> in amity for he never drank no manner of mead which he then put by and <eos>
<sos> anon full privily he voided the more part in his neighbour glass and <eos>
<sos> his neighbour nist not of this wile  and he sat down in that castle <eos>
<sos> with them for to rest him there awhile  thanked be almighty god  <eos>
<sos> this meanwhile this good sister stood by the door and begged them at <eos>
<sos> the reverence of jesu our alther liege lord to leave their wassailing <eos>
<sos> for there was above one quick with child  a gentle dame  whose time <eos>
<sos> hied fast  sir leopold heard on the upfloor cry on high and he wondered <eos>
<sos> what cry that it was whether of child or woman and i marvel  said he  <eos>
<sos> that it be not come or now  meseems it dureth overlong  and he was ware <eos>
<sos> and saw a franklin that hight lenehan on that side the table that was <eos>
<sos> older than any of the tother and for that they both were knights <eos>
<sos> virtuous in the one emprise and eke by cause that he was elder he spoke <eos>
<sos> to him full gently  but  said he  or it be long too she will bring <eos>
<sos> forth by god his bounty and have joy of her childing for she hath <eos>
<sos> waited marvellous long  and the franklin that had drunken said  <eos>
<sos> expecting each moment to be her next  also he took the cup that stood <eos>
<sos> tofore him for him needed never none asking nor desiring of him to <eos>
<sos> drink and  now drink  said he  fully delectably  and he quaffed as far <eos>
<sos> as he might to their both is health for he was a passing good man of his <eos>
<sos> lustiness  and sir leopold that was the goodliest guest that ever sat <eos>
<sos> in scholars  hall and that was the meekest man and the kindest that <eos>
<sos> ever laid husbandly hand under hen and that was the very truest knight <eos>
<sos> of the world one that ever did minion service to lady gentle pledged <eos>
<sos> him courtly in the cup  woman is woe with wonder pondering  <eos>
<sos> now let us speak of that fellowship that was there to the intent to be <eos>
<sos> drunken an they might  there was a sort of scholars along either side <eos>

<sos> merciable is with other his fellows lynch and madden  scholars of <eos>

<sos> of a mastery of him erewhile gested  and of all them  reserved young <eos>
<sos> stephen  he was the most drunken that demanded still of more mead  and <eos>
<sos> beside the meek sir leopold  but on young malachi they waited for that <eos>
<sos> he promised to have come and such as intended to no goodness said how <eos>

<sos> out a matter of some year agone with a woman of eblana in horne is house <eos>
<sos> that now was trespassed out of this world and the self night next <eos>
<sos> before her death all leeches and pothecaries had taken counsel of her <eos>
<sos> case   and they said farther she should live because in the beginning  <eos>
<sos> they said  the woman should bring forth in pain and wherefore they that <eos>
<sos> were of this imagination affirmed how young madden had said truth for <eos>
<sos> he had conscience to let her die  and not few and of these was young <eos>
<sos> lynch were in doubt that the world was now right evil governed as it <eos>
<sos> was never other howbeit the mean people believed it otherwise but the <eos>

<sos> scant said but all cried with one acclaim nay  by our virgin mother  <eos>

<sos> leopold which never durst laugh too open by reason of a strange humour <eos>

<sos> doom and master bloom  at the braggart is side  spoke to him calming <eos>
<sos> words to slumber his great fear  advertising how it was no other thing <eos>
<sos> but a hubbub noise that he heard  the discharge of fluid from the <eos>
<sos> thunderhead  look you  having taken place  and all of the order of a <eos>
<sos> natural phenomenon  <eos>
<sos> but was young boasthard is fear vanquished by calmer is words  no  for he <eos>
<sos> had in his bosom a spike named bitterness which could not by words be <eos>
<sos> done away  and was he then neither calm like the one nor godly like the <eos>
<sos> other  he was neither as much as he would have liked to be either  but <eos>
<sos> could he not have endeavoured to have found again as in his youth the <eos>
<sos> bottle holiness that then he lived withal  indeed no for grace was not <eos>
<sos> there to find that bottle  heard he then in that clap the voice of the <eos>
<sos> god bringforth or  what calmer said  a hubbub of phenomenon  heard  <eos>
<sos> why  he could not but hear unless he had plugged him up the tube <eos>
<sos> understanding  which he had not done   for through that tube he saw <eos>
<sos> that he was in the land of phenomenon where he must for a certain one <eos>
<sos> day die as he was like the rest too a passing show  and would he not <eos>
<sos> accept to die like the rest and pass away  by no means would he though <eos>
<sos> he must nor would he make more shows according as men do with wives <eos>
<sos> which phenomenon has commanded them to do by the book law  then wotted <eos>
<sos> he nought of that other land which is called believe on me  that is the <eos>
<sos> land of promise which behoves to the king delightful and shall be for <eos>
<sos> ever where there is no death and no birth neither wiving nor mothering <eos>
<sos> at which all shall come as many as believe on it  yes  pious had told <eos>
<sos> him of that land and chaste had pointed him to the way but the reason <eos>
<sos> was that in the way he fell in with a certain whore of an eyepleasing <eos>
<sos> exterior whose name  she said  is bird in the hand and she beguiled him <eos>
<sos> wrongways from the true path by her flatteries that she said to him as  <eos>
<sos> ho  you pretty man  turn aside hither and i will show you a brave <eos>
<sos> place  and she lay at him so flatteringly that she had him in her grot <eos>
<sos> which is named two in the bush or  by some learned  carnal <eos>
<sos> concupiscence  <eos>
<sos> this was it what all that company that sat there at commons in manse of <eos>
<sos> mothers the most lusted after and if they met with this whore <eos>
<sos> bird in the hand  which was within all foul plagues  monsters and a <eos>
<sos> wicked devil  they would strain the last but they would make at her and <eos>
<sos> know her  for regarding believe on me they said it was nought else but <eos>
<sos> notion and they could conceive no thought of it for  first  <eos>
<sos> two in the bush whither she ticed them was the very goodliest grot and <eos>
<sos> in it were four pillows on which were four tickets with these words <eos>
<sos> printed on them  pickaback and topsyturvy and shameface and cheek by <eos>
<sos> jowl and  second  for that foul plague allpox and the monsters they <eos>
<sos> cared not for them for preservative had given them a stout shield of <eos>
<sos> oxengut and  third  that they might take no hurt neither from offspring <eos>
<sos> that was that wicked devil by virtue of this same shield which was <eos>

<sos> sometimes godly  mr ape swillale  mr false franklin  mr dainty dixon  <eos>

<sos> very grievous rage that he would presently lift his arm up and spill <eos>
<sos> their souls for their abuses and their spillings done by them <eos>
<sos> contrariwise to his word which forth to bring brenningly biddeth  <eos>
<sos> so thursday sixteenth june patk  dignam laid in clay of an apoplexy and <eos>
<sos> after hard drought  please god  rained  a bargeman coming in by water a <eos>
<sos> fifty mile or thereabout with turf saying the seed wo not sprout  fields <eos>
<sos> athirst  very sadcoloured and stunk mightily  the quags and tofts too  <eos>
<sos> hard to breathe and all the young quicks clean consumed without <eos>
<sos> sprinkle this long while back as no man remembered to be without  the <eos>
<sos> rosy buds all gone brown and spread out blobs and on the hills nought <eos>
<sos> but dry flag and faggots that would catch at first fire  all the world <eos>
<sos> saying  for aught they knew  the big wind of last february a year that <eos>
<sos> did havoc the land so pitifully a small thing beside this barrenness  <eos>
<sos> but by and by  as said  this evening after sundown  the wind sitting in <eos>
<sos> the west  biggish swollen clouds to be seen as the night increased and <eos>
<sos> the weatherwise poring up at them and some sheet lightnings at first <eos>
<sos> and after  past ten of the clock  one great stroke with a long thunder <eos>
<sos> and in a brace of shakes all scamper pellmell within door for the <eos>
<sos> smoking shower  the men making shelter for their straws with a clout or <eos>

<sos> the globes  matriculated at the university to study the mechanics but <eos>

<sos> for him at every turn of the road with a gold manger in each full of <eos>
<sos> the best hay in the market so that he could doss and dung to his <eos>
<sos> heart is content  by this time the father of the faithful  for so they <eos>
<sos> called him  was grown so heavy that he could scarce walk to pasture  to <eos>
<sos> remedy which our cozening dames and damsels brought him his fodder in <eos>

<sos> and so pampered was he that he would suffer nought to grow in all the <eos>
<sos> land but green grass for himself  for that was the only colour to his <eos>
<sos> mind  and there was a board put up on a hillock in the middle of the <eos>

<sos> a bag of rapeseed out he d run amok over half the countryside rooting <eos>

<sos> his matters  says he  i ll make that animal smell hell  says he  with <eos>
<sos> the help of that good pizzle my father left me  but one evening  says <eos>
<sos> mr dixon  when the lord harry was cleaning his royal pelt to go to <eos>
<sos> dinner after winning a boatrace  he had spade oars for himself but the <eos>
<sos> first rule of the course was that the others were to row with <eos>
<sos> pitchforks  he discovered in himself a wonderful likeness to a bull and <eos>
<sos> on picking up a blackthumbed chapbook that he kept in the pantry he <eos>
<sos> found sure enough that he was a lefthanded descendant of the famous <eos>
<sos> champion bull of the romans  bos bovum  which is good bog latin for <eos>
<sos> boss of the show  after that  says mr vincent  the lord harry put his <eos>
<sos> head into a cow is drinkingtrough in the presence of all his courtiers <eos>
<sos> and pulling it out again told them all his new name  then  with the <eos>
<sos> water running off him  he got into an old smock and skirt that had <eos>
<sos> belonged to his grandmother and bought a grammar of the bulls  language <eos>
<sos> to study but he could never learn a word of it except the first <eos>
<sos> personal pronoun which he copied out big and got off by heart and if <eos>
<sos> ever he went out for a walk he filled his pockets with chalk to write <eos>
<sos> it upon what took his fancy  the side of a rock or a teahouse table or <eos>
<sos> a bale of cotton or a corkfloat  in short  he and the bull of ireland <eos>
<sos> were soon as fast friends as an arse and a shirt  they were  says mr <eos>
<sos> stephen  and the end was that the men of the island seeing no help was <eos>
<sos> toward  as the ungrate women were all of one mind  made a wherry raft  <eos>
<sos> loaded themselves and their bundles of chattels on shipboard  set all <eos>
<sos> masts erect  manned the yards  sprang their luff  heaved to  spread <eos>
<sos> three sheets in the wind  put her head between wind and water  weighed <eos>
<sos> anchor  ported her helm  ran up the jolly roger  gave three times <eos>
<sos> three  let the bullgine run  pushed off in their bumboat and put to sea <eos>
<sos> to recover the main of america  which was the occasion  says mr <eos>
<sos> vincent  of the composing by a boatswain of that rollicking chanty  <eos>
<sos> _ pope peter is but a pissabed  <eos>
<sos> a man is a man for a  that _ <eos>
<sos> our worthy acquaintance mr malachi mulligan now appeared in the doorway <eos>
<sos> as the students were finishing their apologue accompanied with a friend <eos>
<sos> whom he had just rencountered  a young gentleman  his name alec bannon  <eos>
<sos> who had late come to town  it being his intention to buy a colour or a <eos>
<sos> cornetcy in the fencibles and list for the wars  mr mulligan was civil <eos>
<sos> enough to express some relish of it all the more as it jumped with a <eos>
<sos> project of his own for the cure of the very evil that had been touched <eos>
<sos> on  whereat he handed round to the company a set of pasteboard cards <eos>
<sos> which he had had printed that day at mr quinnell is bearing a legend <eos>
<sos> printed in fair italics  _mr malachi mulligan  fertiliser and <eos>
<sos> incubator  lambay island_  his project  as he went on to expound  was <eos>
<sos> to withdraw from the round of idle pleasures such as form the chief <eos>
<sos> business of sir fopling popinjay and sir milksop quidnunc in town and <eos>
<sos> to devote himself to the noblest task for which our bodily organism has <eos>
<sos> been framed  well  let us hear of it  good my friend  said mr dixon  i <eos>
<sos> make no doubt it smacks of wenching  come  be seated  both   tis as <eos>
<sos> cheap sitting as standing  mr mulligan accepted of the invitation and  <eos>
<sos> expatiating upon his design  told his hearers that he had been led into <eos>
<sos> this thought by a consideration of the causes of sterility  both the <eos>
<sos> inhibitory and the prohibitory  whether the inhibition in its turn were <eos>
<sos> due to conjugal vexations or to a parsimony of the balance as well as <eos>
<sos> whether the prohibition proceeded from defects congenital or from <eos>
<sos> proclivities acquired  it grieved him plaguily  he said  to see the <eos>
<sos> nuptial couch defrauded of its dearest pledges  and to reflect upon so <eos>
<sos> many agreeable females with rich jointures  a prey to the vilest <eos>
<sos> bonzes  who hide their flambeau under a bushel in an uncongenial <eos>
<sos> cloister or lose their womanly bloom in the embraces of some <eos>
<sos> unaccountable muskin when they might multiply the inlets of happiness  <eos>
<sos> sacrificing the inestimable jewel of their sex when a hundred pretty <eos>
<sos> fellows were at hand to caress  this  he assured them  made his heart <eos>
<sos> weep  to curb this inconvenient  which he concluded due to a <eos>
<sos> suppression of latent heat   having advised with certain counsellors of <eos>
<sos> worth and inspected into this matter  he had resolved to purchase in <eos>
<sos> fee simple for ever the freehold of lambay island from its holder  lord <eos>
<sos> talbot de malahide  a tory gentleman of note much in favour with our <eos>
<sos> ascendancy party  he proposed to set up there a national fertilising <eos>
<sos> farm to be named omphalos with an obelisk hewn and erected after the <eos>
<sos> fashion of egypt and to offer his dutiful yeoman services for the <eos>
<sos> fecundation of any female of what grade of life soever who should there <eos>
<sos> direct to him with the desire of fulfilling the functions of her <eos>
<sos> natural  money was no object  he said  nor would he take a penny for <eos>
<sos> his pains  the poorest kitchenwench no less than the opulent lady of <eos>
<sos> fashion  if so be their constructions and their tempers were warm <eos>
<sos> persuaders for their petitions  would find in him their man  for his <eos>
<sos> nutriment he shewed how he would feed himself exclusively upon a diet <eos>
<sos> of savoury tubercles and fish and coneys there  the flesh of these <eos>
<sos> latter prolific rodents being highly recommended for his purpose  both <eos>
<sos> broiled and stewed with a blade of mace and a pod or two of capsicum <eos>
<sos> chillies  after this homily which he delivered with much warmth of <eos>
<sos> asseveration mr mulligan in a trice put off from his hat a kerchief <eos>
<sos> with which he had shielded it  they both  it seems  had been overtaken <eos>
<sos> by the rain and for all their mending their pace had taken water  as <eos>
<sos> might be observed by mr mulligan is smallclothes of a hodden grey which <eos>
<sos> was now somewhat piebald  his project meanwhile was very favourably <eos>
<sos> entertained by his auditors and won hearty eulogies from all though mr <eos>
<sos> dixon of mary is excepted to it  asking with a finicking air did he <eos>
<sos> purpose also to carry coals to newcastle  mr mulligan however made <eos>
<sos> court to the scholarly by an apt quotation from the classics which  as <eos>
<sos> it dwelt upon his memory  seemed to him a sound and tasteful support of <eos>
<sos> his contention  _talis ac tanta depravatio hujus seculi  o quirites  ut <eos>
<sos> matresfamiliarum nostrae lascivas cujuslibet semiviri libici <eos>
<sos> titillationes testibus ponderosis atque excelsis erectionibus <eos>
<sos> centurionum romanorum magnopere anteponunt_  while for those of ruder <eos>

<sos> fellows inside on the spree  outside the north star hotel and there was <eos>
<sos> no symptom of its budging a quarter of an inch when mr bloom  who was <eos>
<sos> anything but a professional whistler  endeavoured to hail it by <eos>
<sos> emitting a kind of a whistle  holding his arms arched over his head  <eos>
<sos> twice  <eos>

<sos> there was nothing for it but put a good face on the matter and foot it <eos>
<sos> which they accordingly did  so  bevelling around by mullett is and the <eos>
<sos> signal house which they shortly reached  they proceeded perforce in the <eos>
<sos> direction of amiens street railway terminus  mr bloom being handicapped <eos>
<sos> by the circumstance that one of the back buttons of his trousers had  <eos>
<sos> to vary the timehonoured adage  gone the way of all buttons though  <eos>
<sos> entering thoroughly into the spirit of the thing  he heroically made <eos>
<sos> light of the mischance  so as neither of them were particularly pressed <eos>
<sos> for time  as it happened  and the temperature refreshing since it <eos>
<sos> cleared up after the recent visitation of jupiter pluvius  they <eos>
<sos> dandered along past by where the empty vehicle was waiting without a <eos>
<sos> fare or a jarvey  as it so happened a dublin united tramways company is <eos>
<sos> sandstrewer happened to be returning and the elder man recounted to his <eos>
<sos> companion Ã  propos of the incident his own truly miraculous escape of <eos>
<sos> some little while back  they passed the main entrance of the great <eos>
<sos> northern railway station  the starting point for belfast  where of <eos>
<sos> course all traffic was suspended at that late hour and passing the <eos>
<sos> backdoor of the morgue  a not very enticing locality  not to say <eos>
<sos> gruesome to a degree  more especially at night  ultimately gained the <eos>
<sos> dock tavern and in due course turned into store street  famous for its <eos>
<sos> c division police station  between this point and the high at present <eos>
<sos> unlit warehouses of beresford place stephen thought to think of ibsen  <eos>

<sos> place  first turning on the right  while the other who was acting as <eos>
<sos> his fidus achates inhaled with internal satisfaction the smell of <eos>
<sos> james rourke is city bakery  situated quite close to where they were  <eos>

<sos> life  earn your bread  o tell me where is fancy bread  at rourke is the <eos>
<sos> baker is it is said  <eos>
<sos> en route to his taciturn and  not to put too fine a point on it  not <eos>
<sos> yet perfectly sober companion mr bloom who at all events was in <eos>
<sos> complete possession of his faculties  never more so  in fact <eos>
<sos> disgustingly sober  spoke a word of caution re the dangers of <eos>
<sos> nighttown  women of ill fame and swell mobsmen  which  barely <eos>
<sos> permissible once in a while though not as a habitual practice  was of <eos>
<sos> the nature of a regular deathtrap for young fellows of his age <eos>
<sos> particularly if they had acquired drinking habits under the influence <eos>
<sos> of liquor unless you knew a little jiujitsu for every contingency as <eos>
<sos> even a fellow on the broad of his back could administer a nasty kick if <eos>
<sos> you did not look out  highly providential was the appearance on the <eos>
<sos> scene of corny kelleher when stephen was blissfully unconscious but for <eos>
<sos> that man in the gap turning up at the eleventh hour the finis might <eos>
<sos> have been that he might have been a candidate for the accident ward or  <eos>

<sos> freely distributed in machine readable form accessible by the widest <eos>
<sos> array of equipment including outdated equipment  many small donations <eos>
<sos>   1 to  5 000  are particularly important to maintaining tax exempt <eos>
<sos> status with the irs  <eos>

<sos> charities and charitable donations in all 50 states of the united <eos>
<sos> states  compliance requirements are not uniform and it takes a <eos>
<sos> considerable effort  much paperwork and many fees to meet and keep up <eos>
<sos> with these requirements  we do not solicit donations in locations <eos>
<sos> where we have not received written confirmation of compliance  to send <eos>
<sos> donations or determine the status of compliance for any particular <eos>
<sos> state visit www gutenberg org donate <eos>
<sos> while we cannot and do not solicit contributions from states where we <eos>
<sos> have not met the solicitation requirements  we know of no prohibition <eos>
<sos> against accepting unsolicited donations from donors in such states who <eos>
<sos> approach us with offers to donate  <eos>

<sos> section 5  general information about project gutenberg tm electronic works <eos>
<sos> professor michael s  hart was the originator of the project <eos>
<sos> gutenberg tm concept of a library of electronic works that could be <eos>
<sos> freely shared with anyone  for forty years  he produced and <eos>
<sos> distributed project gutenberg tm ebooks with only a loose network of <eos>
<sos> volunteer support  <eos>
<sos> project gutenberg tm ebooks are often created from several printed <eos>
<sos> editions  all of which are confirmed as not protected by copyright in <eos>
<sos> the u s  unless a copyright notice is included  thus  we do not <eos>
<sos> necessarily keep ebooks in compliance with any particular paper <eos>
<sos> edition  <eos>

<sos> facility  www gutenberg org <eos>
